author: PapaCharlie9
body:
I understand the desire, but those sparse expirations, low volumes, and crazy wide bid/asks are all warning flags to steer clear of options on those ETFs. You're just throwing away money trading those options.

A better idea would be to figure out what the top 3 holdings of each of those funds are and see if any of those companies have highly liquid options. Then trade options on those companies as a sort of proxy.

For example, the top three holdings of SOXX are AVGO, NVDA, TXN. All three have decent liquidity.

https://www.zacks.com/funds/etf/SOXX/holding

You can then use an asset correlation app to see which of those individual stocks with liquid options most closely correlates to the fund's performance. For example:

[Portfolio Visualizer asset correlation](https://www.portfoliovisualizer.com/asset-correlations?s=y&symbols=SOXX+AVGO+NVDA+TXN&timePeriod=2&tradingDays=60&months=36)

TXN is the closest with a .84 correlation to SOXX.



FWIW, you're paying an obscene expense ratio on ARKK. You'd likely make more money over the long run holding QQQ instead of ARKK.
